SP.P: Must I be patient, Madam? must I permit the direst villain to survive?—and do you plead for him?—no, if my honour was not pledg'd to Dormer not to take up this affair without him, by my soul a moment shou'd not pass before my sword shou'd make its passage to the traitor's heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: What traitor's heart? you must not call him traitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Amazement! Lady Davenant, you confound me:—'tis too flagrant. Have I not proof certain?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: No, no; I tell you, wretched man, you have no proof—and when you have—

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: What then!—why then I'd drag him from the altar: stab him, tho' your fond arms protected him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: You don't know what you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: 'Tis you that say you know not what;—'tis you, alas! whom this confusion painfully betrays;—you, whom a fatal weakness forces to protect the blackest of mankind. By Heaven that gave me life, I thought you late a miracle of truth and goodness: I approach'd you with a reverence that border'd on idolatry. I leave you now with mournful pity and regret; I go, because I can no longer bear to be spectator of the fall of such exalted virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P:
Lost, lost, forever lost!—go, miserable youth; enjoy the respite of a short mistake: the moment that clears up my innocence, lets fall despair on thee: what a tremendous scene will that unfold! a father husband to thy wife!—It must be so: a multitude of circumstances now confirm it:—this, this it is that solves the mys∣tery of his unnatural conduct: this is the latent
dagger of his mind: this is his horror: this the injury so unatoneable to Dormer. The very hour in which he took Sir Harry's equipage; his journey to the continent; his stay abroad, and his long silence, whilst in absence from me, rise in horrible array, a host of witnesses, de∣posing to the dreadful truth. Inextricable dis∣tress! what can be done? I see no light:—Fate labours as with mother's pangs, and the fell babe of horror, hell-begotten, presses to the birth—Father of mercies, give me thy support!—Without there! who attends?
Is your Lord still at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My Lord is in the library with Sir Harry Harlow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Has Captain Davenant been there?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, Madam, he has this moment left the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P:
Run to my Lord, tell him to give nobody admittance till I have seen him; and desire Sir Harry Harlow to come hither imme∣diately. [Exit Servant.] I am not in the fault: I have not driven him to this desperate act. Be witness for me, truth, I have not wilfully oc∣casion'd his disgust, but studied to my utmost to obey and please him. If by Sir Harry's means I can hold off this fatal explanation, till Lord Davenant takes his measures, an inter∣view
perhaps may be avoided that is horrible to think of.—I sent to you, Sir Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: I flew with ardour at your sum∣mons; and I await your pleasure, with a heart that throbs to serve you—with a heart, dear Lady, that can only cease to love, when it shall cease to beat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: 'Tis well; I mean to put your friendship to the proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Friendship indeed! but call it by what name you will; my life is your's; com∣mand it to what purpose you see fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Pray don't mistake yourself or me—You lent your chariot to my Lord this morn∣ing?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Madam!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Come, come, I know you did: I saw it at my door: I saw him enter it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Then I must not dispute the point with you;—to any other questioner I yield no answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P:
'Twill be a service most essential to my happiness, if you will consent to screen Lord Davenant for a while; I wou'd not put this on you, but for most pressing reasons; nor do I mean that any risque or imputation thence arising shou'd ultimately fall on you: there∣fore, I do beseech you for an hour or so that you will be invisible to all enquirers, but above
all to Captain Dormer and Charles Davenant▪ Return not to my Lord, but quit this house immediately; and if I might prevail, you shou'd not enter your own for some time; they'll seek you there, and if their fury shall compel you to an explanation, I must tremble for the conse∣quences.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Most amiable of women!—I per∣ceive your drift: you act too nobly by an un∣deserving husband; but I make no appeal; implicitly I shall obey, because 'tis your com∣mand;—and tho' my life were made the sacri∣fice, what were more glorious than to die for you?—one word, one kind approving look can overpay the purchase; grant that before we part, and at your feet I dedicate for ever to your service my devoted heart.
SP.STAGE: Enter Davenant hastily, followed by Dormer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Villain, stand up, and answer me. Now, Dormer, now will you believe me? Have we found you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Draw, wretch, for I am Dormer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: You are mad: or sheath your sword, or pass its murderous point thro' me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P:
O shame, shame, shame! and have I liv'd to see it? O mortal blow to modesty!—Let there be no fidelity in woman, no faith henceforth in man!—Come forth, thou shelter'd
coward! answer with thy life: it is not for thine own enormities alone, 'tis for her's also thou must now account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: I'll answer nothing, but to every tittle of your charge to say 'tis grosly false. Set∣tle your own precedencies;—I am ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Will you hear reason? Dormer, Charles, I do conjure you both, forbear!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Give their rage way: they chuse a notable occasion in a lady's presence to display their valour!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Our wrongs are such as will not bear delay; nor will we trust to one who can change names, shift persons, counterfeit even death itself to ruin innocence and mock avenging justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: I don't know what you say; but such assassin-like attacks deserve no answer, nor admit of any explanation. You, Mr. Davenant, know me well; you know I may and will be found:—appoint your place, I'll meet you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Follow us then!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Help, help!—You shall not stir.—This is too much.—You are deceiv'd; he's in∣nocent—help, help!
SP.STAGE: [Runs to the door, and meets Lord Davenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: What is this uproar? who has fright∣ed you?—Hah! Dormer here?—Sir Harry, what has pass'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Pass'd, my Lord! nothing; all is mystery to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why did she scream out?—A word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: [To Dormer.] Dormer, contain your∣self; there's something here that's dark and ter∣rifying: say nothing to my father;—let us with∣draw, and wait below; there can be no escape. Nay follow me, I do conjure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: O Lady Davenant, reconcile my mind to this mysterious conduct, or break my heart at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: What then becomes of mine? it bursts distracted with o'erwhelming grief.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Look to my Lady.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: No, no; regard not me; I shall not fail; Heaven sends me strength for my appointed task.—Let me be private with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Not for the world:—my thoughts are terrible; I am possess'd by fiends—stay, and be witness to my shame, whilst I confess the black accompt which I must pass with Dormer: I have betray'd his sister; ruin'd her by for∣geries and falsehoods, as I did you, Louisa;—married her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Infamous deed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, there is rebellion in my blood; his sword must let it out:—therefore no more, but let me pass.
SP.STAGE: [As he is going out, Lady Davenant stops him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Hold, hold! you must not stir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: What is't you mean? why do you cross me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: To save you from a meeting worse than death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: To save your lover from a meeting that may lead to death.—Oh! whilst you live, speak truth:—'tis love of Dormer raises this alarm. Have I not found the cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: No, you've not found the cause:—wou'd that you never could!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Be caution'd by your Lady, and impute to her concern no other than the purest motive;—my life upon it, you will find it such▪ Alas, unhappy man, what treasure have you cast away? Hear her, console her, be advis'd by her: recover, if you can, her forfeited esteem. She is a miracle of goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P:
Dost think me so far sunk in honour, as to shrink from this discussion? Dormer's en∣titled to an honourable satisfaction, and I shall give it him immediately. Before we part how∣ever, Lady Davenant, let me own that I am penetrated with remorse for my conduct to you. Tho' I ask nothing for myself, I am not out of hope that you will cast an eye of pity and pro∣tection on that guiltless sufferer, who, if I fall, will be the partner of your widowhood:—she is young and beautiful; and, if your influence over Dormer is exerted in her favour, she may
retrieve the unhappy error into which I led her.—Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Yet, yet prevent him.—Stay;—she has a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: What do you tell me? speak that word again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: She has a husband—and that hus∣band—how shall I pronounce it?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Go on: I'll have it, tho' it breathes destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: That husband is your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Death to my soul!—My son!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Your son this morning married Dor∣mer's sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why do I live a moment?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Stop your rash hand.—What phrenzy seizes you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Why does the earth not yawn, and whelm me to the centre?—Oh what a day of dreadful retribution!—Why was this marriage secret?—which of you was privy to it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I knew it not, nor had suspicion of it:—few hours are past since he disclos'd it to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Fatal concealment!—horrible event!—O God, O God, into what misery have I plung'd my son!—Does he know what I have done?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P:
Nor he nor Dormer know it:—take
this comfort also to your heart; it is as yet a mar∣riage but in form: the day is not yet passed, in which their hands were join'd.—Heaven in its vengeance has remember'd mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Call my son here directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: There let me interpose again. Take a short time for serious meditation: we will assist your thoughts. Your friend here has already struck one spark of light amidst your dark despair; patient reflection may bring more in view. Perhaps this meeting with your son, which you in your mind's present agitation are for hastening, prudence may postpone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Speak on, for there is something in your voice like comfort; something that falls upon my ear, like music in the dead of night after distressful dreams.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Oh! if a few calm words can lull your ear, think how repentance may asswage your soul:—for so much of your offence as falls on me alone, I thank Heaven's mercy for its aid, I can forgive it; nay, my Lord, I have forgiven it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Nay, but you must abhor me; darkness must be less opposite to light, than I to innocence:—so loathsome am I to myself, I shou'd despise the person that cou'd pity me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Come to your chamber; follow your guardian angel where she leads you:—If I can serve you in this melancholy hour, command me; if I am in your way, dismiss me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I pray you leave me not—I have a thing to tell you—It is not known to man, nor can your heart conceive, how dire a deed I've had in meditation:—there was a thought struck on my mind too terrible for utterance: but it is past: this stroke, that cuts up all resource of hope, cuts up the bloody purpose that I had in hand. And now I feel as it were two na∣tures:—my good and evil genius seem at strife within me; this touches me with human kind∣ness and remorse; that tears me with despair and horror. How it will end I know not; for all command is lost, and my mind drives like a wreck before the tempest.—Go with my Lady Davenant; stay by her, I beseech you. I will retire to my chamber. Farewell!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: An Apartment in Lord Davenant's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: 'TIS near an hour I have waited here, and still this man appears not. I shou'd suspect he had escap'd me, if Davenant had not positively said, there was no other way for him to pass but thro' this room. No solitude can be more silent than the house:—they are in conference still. My mind is on the rack; I am tortur'd with uncertainty—He comes—My Lady Davenant!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Is your friend yet return'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: No, Madam; Captain Davenant is not yet come back.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: But you expect him soon?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: With every moment. Has your Lady∣ship any thing in command for him that I can deliver?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: No, Sir: my servants have my or∣ders, when he comes, to beg that I may see him instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P:
Stop, I beseech you, for a moment
stop! is it with him alone you will confer? am I not worthy of a word? a look?—or will you turn, but when Sir Harry kneels?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Yes; I wou'd turn to Dormer, cou'd I see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Am I not Dormer? is he not before you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: To memory he is present, not to sight. The picture of him in my mind is clear and spotless, trac'd with benevolence and truth and courage; it beams with candour, and it glows with love.—The picture in my eye is false and faded, smear'd by some spurious dawber, patcht, distorted; the open smile of honour wrinkled to a leer of livid jealousy—a libel, not a likeness of a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Hear only what I have to offer: stay, and hear me:—she's gone and gives no ear: unjust, disdainful!—Hah! by my hopes, her scorn shall be repay'd—her paramour ap∣proaches—You are found, Sir—
At last we are alone; and tho' I find you under Lady Davenant's roof, yet your protectress be∣ing absent, that shall no longer be your safe∣guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: I own I wish'd to have avoided you; but since we are met, proceed to state your charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: No wonder you shou'd wish to avoid me, for you have done a base unmanly injury to a defenceless orphan; by a pretended ge∣nerosity you stole into her good opinion, mar∣ried and abandoned her. Base as this is, there is a meanness in the act, that makes it more de∣testable than open villainy:—you counterfeited death; paltry expedient! which not only gives your tongue the lie, but stamps it on your life.—Draw then! defend yourself; for 'tis not now a counterfeited death, but the reality, that must determine one of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Take your own course; I shall repel assault: but first, by way of caution, hear me:—'Twas once my chance, as it is now, to be call'd out by a rash angry boy, to answer with my sword for an imputed injury to a lady, whom he took on himself to protect. I met him, for his rage was deaf to reason: being master of the sword, I soon disarmed my hot antagonist:—when I had given him life, I gave him proof of his mistake:—the youth was satisfied, and sav'd. A second instance may not be so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P:
I understand you; but the proofs, which in his instance follow'd, now precede our interview. You'll not deny the equipage was your's; that you was in it; that my sister saw you, call'd out to you to stop: you did; but, looking out, discover'd her, and basely took to flight?—these facts bring home to you unanswer∣able
proof, and leave you nothing but con∣fession and atonement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: This arrogance compels me to an act, which, in compassion to your youth, and the misfortunes that hang over it, I fain would have avoided. I draw my sword, not to answer to your charge, but to chastise your insult:—Still I bear so little of revenge about me, that if you'll satisfy my honour with the least apology, I promise you an hour shall not pass before I'll clear my innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: That you can never do; for if by any palliation you could hope to smooth away your injuries to my sister, still there remains a black account of crimes, which nothing but your life can expiate: These eyes have seen you at the feet of Lady Davenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: Stop your blaspheming tongue!—die, madman, in your error!
SP.STAGE: Marianne runs in, followed by Davenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Hold, for the love of Heaven!—Charles, Charles, beat down their swords! See, see, my brother bleeds.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: 'Tis but a scratch.—Stand off!

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What is your quarrel? Why does he assault you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Can you ask that? has your fright blinded you? do you not recollect that face?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I never to my knowledge saw that gen∣tleman before.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: I did suspect this, Dormer; and on that account I brought your sister with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Have patience, if you please—Come hither, Marianne, look at that gentleman: Do you forget, or will you not acknowledge your husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Husband! I tell you he's a perfect stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: If you say this from fear, or false re∣spect for what may follow to affect my safety, you do wrong both to yourself and me: there∣fore I charge you answer me sincerely and with∣out disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: As Heaven shall judge me I have spoke the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: I'm satisfied:—Sir Harry Harlow, I perceive my error; and for so much as affects this Lady, I sincerely ask your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: So much for one of your mistakes; there is another, which you must atone for:—a little patience will clear all; reserve your spirits for that trial;—you now conceive the reason why my Lady Davenant interpos'd in my behalf: she knew my innocence, and therefore stopt your hand; when you know her's, the sword you pointed at my breast, take care you turn it not upon your own: none but the same de∣sender can preserve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P:
I own, the circumstance of this mistake has cleared that part of Lady Davenant's con∣duct;
it only now remains to account why you was found upon your knees before her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: How else should I approach her? When you know all her virtues, you will wor∣ship too:—the presence of an angel must demand our knees.—But you are wounded, Sir; you bleed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: 'Tis nothing; a mere scratch; your point just glanc'd upon my arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: 'Tis well it is no worse. Good night to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Before you go, one word with you, Sir Harry—I am certainly inform'd the person we are now in search of was in your chariot this morning, when an accident stopt it in the street where this Lady lives: I demand of you as a man of honour to inform me who that per∣son is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P: When you take that for granted, Charles, which I have not admitted, and there∣on ground a question I'm not bound to an∣swer, you must give me leave to say, you have already had the only satisfaction I shall give. I have been once arraign'd, am now acquitted, and shall no longer plead to interrogatories.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Permit me then to tell you, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir H. H.
SP.P:
No, tell me nothing I ought not to hear; for I regard you much too well to start a quarrel with you;—rather let me tell you, Charles, what you should hear, and thank me
for—you and your friend there have arraign'd a lady perfect in all goodness, construing the purest motives into criminality. I see her com∣ing, and shall leave you this fair opportunity to make atonement: when you have done that, if you have any farther difference to compose with me, I shall attend your call when, where, and how you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: But that I know your heart, I should despair of pardon; suffer me to hope you will forgive my most unjust suspicion, and receive into your favour my beloved Marianne.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: This is the Lady—if I survey her for a while with melancholy admiration I shall not offend:—is this a form to combat rude mis∣fortune? that it should enter in the heart of man to injure such a creature! that artifice and wrong might be employ'd to gain her I can com∣prehend, but that they should be a resource for leaving her, surpasses my conception: I find till now imagination could not reach the guilt of her betrayer.—Give me your hand, my dear, you come into a melancholy house: I cannot welcome you as I would wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
And cause there is for melancholy: wherever I am present, it pursues me: I am the bit∣ter fountain of your sorrow. My fatal marriage with this noble youth has been the bane and poison of your peace. I pray you send me
hence; dismiss me like a thing abhorr'd; a pes∣tilence, that, if you harbour it, will pay your hospitality with death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Not so; misfortune strengthens your interest in my heart. You have more claims upon me than you know of. You are still married in your heart to Davenant; so was I once to Dormer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Oh! I shall sink with shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Had I been, as you are, thus wretched, thus betray'd, nor wife nor widow, but a nameless orphan, the sport of villainy, affliction's victim—you had a brother once, in whose brave heart I shou'd have rais'd that pity you excite in mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Oh, plead for me, some friend! I dare not speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: No, Dormer, no: when I forgive, you shall not owe it to an advocate:—but let that rest; things of more moment press.—You must not see your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Why not? your words alarm me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: His situation would alarm you more: some strange disorder suddenly has seiz'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Say rather some strange passion of the mind.—You told him of my marriage?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I did, and he receiv'd it like a stroke of death; his frame convuls'd with passion.—I must for ever lament your not consulting him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Does he resent it highly?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: We'll talk of that hereafter; for the present you must avoid an interview. If you remain in the house, retire to your own chamber, and let her accompany you;—take Mr. Dor∣mer with you too.—Go, my dear child, go with your friend—so you may call him still.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: My heart's too full to utter what it feels.—In the expressive language of your eyes I read my melancholy fate.—Farewell!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Well, Sir, you'll follow that unhappy pair;—or do you wait to spring some new de∣tection?—Fie upon you!—What blemish does your scrutinizing eye discover, that you so sted∣fastly peruse me over?—Oh, that a taint so sickly as suspicion should find admittance in a hero's breast!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.STAGE: [runs to Lady Davenant, and falls at her feet]
SP.P: Hear me, divine Louisa, hear your re∣pentant Dormer:—let me kneel for pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Rise, rise!—this is no time for ex∣planation.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Stop not my words, now they have found their way, but let me pour them and my tears, thus kneeling at your feet.—Before my tyes lose sight of you, confirm my pardon; tell me you forgive what my impatient phrenzy, what my mad suspicion utter'd.—Penitence ne'er struck a human heart more deep than mine.—Daemons have curs'd the sun, I have done more—I have arraign'd thy virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Rise, I desire you, rise! you have my full forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Oh! first and last sole object of my heart! how can I thank thee as I ought?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: If to regain and keep your place in my affection is your wish, spare the attempt to thank me, nor by this warmth of passion draw aside my thoughts from the sad theme that fills them. That I have lov'd you, Dor∣mer, and still love, superior to disguise, ac∣cept my free confession; but when example meets me of the precipitancy of passion in Da∣venant's case; of the deceitfulness of gratitude in Marianne's; I will be guided only by esteem; and on your delicacy, on your discretion in this mournful crisis will depend, if that affection which I now acknowledge shall subsist or cease.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: The air is fresher here: motion re∣vives me.

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P: I wish it may: and yet your colour changes; your eyes look heavy, and betoken pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I've wearied them with writing. Take the papers—This to my son; to Lady Davenant this; and this to Dormer.—Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P:
What's that? another pang?—and now
it shakes you like an ague fit: pray be per∣suaded; let your physician be sent for.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: What can he do? my wounds are in the soul. Give me your arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P: How cold your hand is on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: No matter: 'twill pass off.—I'm better now. Make all things ready. I will be gone to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P: How can you travel with these pains upon you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I shall feel no pains upon my journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P: I fear, my Lord, you are not fit to undertake your journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I fear so too:—but, be that as it may, let me have all things ready. Have you put up those parchments for my son?

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P: They are in the box, seal'd and directed for Mr. Davenant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: That's very well—now tell my Lady that I desire to see her.—A word with you be∣fore you go:—You will find I have not forgot your services; they wou'd have done credit to a better cause; but as I have put you now above necessity, I hope I have put you above mean∣ness also.

SP.SPEAKER: Paget.
SP.P: It has not been my choice, but my misfortune. I shall send Lady Davenant to you, and hope she will prevail with you to postpone your journey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Dav.
SP.P:
My journey must be quickened,
not postponed.—This medicine works too slowly;—but here's a remedy of more dispatch:—Apply it then!—Misery like mine acquits the suicide; when law strikes short, justice should arm the culprit's hand.—The occasion's apt:—In death there's but one pang, in life a thousand thousand multiplied calamities.—Now, now I'll do it.—Hah! I'm interrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: I am told you have been seized with sudden indisposition;—what is the matter?—How are you affected?—Are you resolved upon departing immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I am resolved: my mind is gone be∣fore me; and when I am departed, I shall be∣queath you to your heart's first choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: What do you meditate?—Your words, your looks are ominous. What was that thing you huddled in your bosom, as I entered?—My Lord, my Lord, beware of self-destruc∣tion!—Your bosom labours, your breath flut∣ters, and your eyes—Oh horrible! what are these ghastly symptoms?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P:
If any consolation could have rescued me, thine would have been the medicine of my mind;—thou would'st have been the saving an∣gel, thou most excellent, most injured of wo∣men!—But I have sate in council with my rea∣son, ransack'd all the resources of my soul, and questioned every rising thought, if it could show me hope:—In all my composition, there is not one trace; night and despair possess me, and there is nothing like a ray of light, save only
what the mortal drug administers, that now is sapping the strong-hold of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Poison!—Oh let me fly, and bring you instant help.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Hold, I command you:—Assistance is too late; nor would I suffer it, if it came.—'Sdeath! I were a beast without a soul;—I, that Have kept my station with the highest, now to sink where infamy won't own me;—the outcast of society, the pointing-stock of scorn, and feed on offal scraps of pity, thrown by charitable fools, to comfort me!—it is not to be borne!—Despair seized me, and I took poison.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Be not extreme with him in judg∣ment, merciful Disposer!—He comes, but not in confidence:—despair compels him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: I thank you.—O Louisa! best of women!—if I had confidence to pray, it should be for such blessings on your future days, as might redeem and recompence your sufferings past. And yet I'll strive—Oh horrible! it must not be.—My soul is rent with agony:—Methought, as I looked up, I saw a thousand threatening faces, that forbade my prayer. Oh hide me in your arms!—Stand off again! lest I infect and stain your purity with my unholy touch.—Blest may you be! thrice blest in Dor∣mer's arms!—May Heaven shower down on your united hearts perpetual harmony and love! And for the hateful barrier of my life, thus, thus I burst it—
SP.STAGE: [Stabs himself, and she catches his arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Let go my arm! my soul is in a loathsome prison, and this stroke delivers it.
SP.STAGE: [Stabs again, and drops on one knee, holding the dagger still in his hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Help! for the love of Heaven, some help!—
SP.STAGE: Enter Davenant, and at another door Servants.
SP.P: O Charles! your father has destroy'd himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Merciful God! he is dying.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: The agonies of death are on him. Assist me to take him off:—I can't support him;—he will die upon the floor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Yes, yes, 'tis over!—tell not my son the cause till I am dead. This was the only kindness I could shew him. I am sorry to pre∣sent a spectacle so bloody to you both: but poison work'd too sluggishly, nor could I bear its agonies—oh keep her from the sight of me!—she comes—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What have we here? Oh horrible! what dying man is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord D.
SP.P: Oh hide me! cover me with clouds: I sink, I die—have pity for me, Heaven!—'tis past.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Let me come to him: let me see his face. 'Tis he! avenging Heaven! it is my husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorm.
SP.P: Lord Davenant your husband!—com∣plicated misery!

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Her husband, and my father!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: The horrid mystery is solv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Then let me die;—let my heart burst at once, and bury me for ever in oblivion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: No, whilst my arms, my friendship can uphold you, you shall never fall.—Come from the body, Charles:—cease to contemplate that bloody object.

SP.SPEAKER: Dav.
SP.P: Nay, but be silent—it is done—he's dead.—I will be dumb henceforth; but have some care of me, for if my reason fails, and not remembering he was my father, I shou'd shock nature's hearing with a curse, 'twill be the brain's depravity, and not the heart's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady D.
SP.P: Alas, unhappy friends, my spirits will not serve to give you consolation; but let us patiently await, and it will come from Heaven:—the same dispensing hand, that to the blameless bosom deals the wound, will in its own good time administer the cure.

LG.L: TO-night two sketches we've held up to view,
One of the old school, t'other of the new.
As for my Lady's portrait, I can't boast
Its likeness, for the original is lost:
In times foregone the colouring might be good,
But now it scarce resembles flesh and blood:
The pencil's chaste—but where, I wou'd demand,
Are the soft touches of a modern hand?
Where the fond languish that our masters steal?
The tempting bosom that our dames reveal?
Where the high plume that speaks the towering soul?
Where the bright gloss that varnishes the whole?
The habit regimental, smart cockade,
And the neat ankle roguishly display'd?
None, none of these—a piece of mere still life,
Where not one feature marks the modern wife.
Lay the good dame aside—and now behold
My Lord appears!—These tints are fresh and bold;
This is the life itself. Mark! what a grace
Beams in his high-born tyranny of face!
He breathes; he speaks. Cards, harlots, horses, dice
Croud the back-ground with attributes of vice:
This, this is something like; these colours give
Some semblance of a man: 'Tis so we live,
'Tis so we look, you cry—behold once more!
The suicide is welt'ring in his gore.
Hah! does it strike you? say, do you still cry,
'Tis so we live?—so live, and so you'll die.
But one word more on Lady Davenant's part,
We hope 'tis Nature; you believe it Art.
Search your own bosoms; if you find her there
'Tis well: if not, I wou'd to Heaven she were!
